questions.text: The gross specimen of the pancreas from a patient who died of acute pancreatitis is shown below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fat necrosis

The given specimen shows yellow nodules with areas of chalky-white deposits, which are suggestive of fat necrosis. Fat necrosis results from the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification).

questions.text: What is the goven pedigree chart indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mitochondrial disorder

The given pedigree chart is of Mitochondrial disorder.

Mitochondrial disorders are inherited through the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is passed from mother to offspring. This means that a mitochondrial disorder pedigree will exhibit a maternal inheritance pattern.

questions.text: Most specific feature of the disease shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Coarctation of Aorta

The diagnosis is Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome (TS) has a 45,X karyotype. The clinical features of TS result from haploinsufficiency of multiple X chromosomal genes (e.g., Short Stature Homeobox, SHOX). TS is characterized by bilateral streak gonads, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and multiple congenital anomalies in phenotypic females. Prenatally, a diagnosis of TS is usually made incidentally after chorionic villous sampling or amniocentesis for unrelated reasons, such as advanced maternal age.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen in the spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Embolization 

The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen. The most common cause of splenic infarcts is a thromboembolism. The pattern of ischemic necrosis in the spleen is coagulative necrosis.

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Autosomal dominant

The pedigree chart shows an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. Autosomal dominant conditions are manifested in the heterozygous state, hence at least one parent of an index case is usually affected. In this mode of inheritance, both males and females are affected and both can transmit the condition. When an affected person marries an unaffected one, every child has one in two chance of having the disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and macroorchidism. Cytogenetic analysis reveals an expanded CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene. Which of the following genetic disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fragile X syndrome

intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and macroorchidism, along with an expanded CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene on cytogenetic analysis, is consistent with Fragile X syndrome. Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CGG) in the FMR1 gene, leading to reduced expression of the Fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP). This results in neurological and developmental abnormalities, including intellectual disability, behavioral problems, and characteristic facial features. Down syndrome is characterized by trisomy 21 (an extra copy of chromosome 21) and typically presents with intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and other associated features. Turner syndrome is characterized by monosomy X (45,X), leading to features such as short stature and ovarian insufficiency. Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by an extra X chromosome in males (47,XXY), leading to features such as tall stature, hypogonadism, and infertility.

questions.text: During the autopsy of a 90-year-old woman, a normal-looking liver was noted. The following microscopic appearance of hepatocytes was noted. Which of the following cellular mechanisms is likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Autophagocytosis

The given image shows brownish lipofuscin granules within the liver cells. It is composed of lipid- containing residues of lysosomal digestion that are formed due to autophagocytosis.
Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment that is due to free radical injury to the tissue. It is prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients or patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

questions.text: An elderly man diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung underwent surgical resection. Histopathological examination of the resected hilar lymph nodes revealed the following finding as given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anthracotic pigmentation 

The given clinical scenario and histopathological image of the lymph node showing abundant black- colored pigment within the macrophages are characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis.
The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages and then transported to the hilar lymph nodes, which causes the blackening of the tissues. The carbon dust may also induce fibroblastic reaction.

questions.text: A patient presents with ascites and edema. On examination, JVP was elevated. Gross examination finding of the tissue biopsy is shown. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A-V congestion

The clinical vignette of ascites, edema with elevated jvp point towards congestive hepatopathy. The image show nutmeg liver and chronic passive congestion of the liver. It usually occurs due to congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A girl with intellectual disability presents to the OPD with the following finding (image below). Cardiac evaluation shows a congenital endocardial cushion defect. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Down’s syndrome

A palmar crease is a type of crease on the palm. A single transverse palmar crease also called simian crease is sometimes associated with Down syndrome

questions.text: What's the key intracellular iron storage protein in the hepatocytes of a 45-year-old male with abdominal enlargement, yellow skin, sclera, hepatomegaly, and jaundice and the given liver biopsy findings on Prussian blue stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hemosiderin

Hemosiderin is an iron storage complex produced during the breakdown of ferritin and phagocytosed haemoglobin (e.g., after red blood cell destruction). It may be found in various tissues (e.g., alveolar macrophages, liver parenchyma) or urine, depending on the underlying pathology (e.g., pulmonary haemorrhage, hemochromatosis, and intravascular hemolysis).

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for the newborn boy brought to the neonatology department with a drooping eyelid, a deep groove between the nose and the mouth, and a depressed nose tip?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Noonan syndrome 

Based on abnormalities in his facial features, such as a drooping eyelid, mouth has a deep groove between the nose and the mouth, along with a depressed nose tip; the neonate is suffering from Noonan syndrome. Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition associated with a normal karyotype. It is thought to be caused by a defect in a gene on chromosome 12.

questions.text: A 9-year-old African boy presents with the findings shown below. A biopsy is consistent with a malignancy that has infiltrated the bone marrow of the jaw. This neoplasm is linked to a virus that prefers which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lymphocytes

Burkitt's lymphoma/leukemia, more common in children, is a rapidly growing cancer linked to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The endemic form usually presents as a jaw tumor, spreading to the bone marrow and other sites, while the non-endemic form features large abdominal tumors. Immunodeficiency-related cases often involve lymph nodes and can resemble acute leukemia. The EBV gp350/220 glycoprotein binds to CD21/CD35 receptors on B cells, facilitating viral entry and infection.

questions.text: A male patient with hemoptysis. On examination, a hilar mass was present. The histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the cells were positive for p40. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Squamous cell carcinoma of lung

The patient's presentation with hemoptysis and a hilar mass showing keratin pearls on histopathology and cells showing p40 positivity on immunohistochemistry is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of lung.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has become increasingly clumsy over 6 months. Examination reveals leukocoria and no red reflex in the left eye. A tumor is found, and after enucleation, microscopic analysis shows loss of cell cycle control. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Retinoblastoma

The most common ocular tumor in children, typically presenting around age 1 with leukocoria. Histologically, it features small blue cells and areas of pink necrosis. More differentiated cases may show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old obese woman has experienced heartburn from gastric reflux for the past 5 years after eating large meals. She undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, and a biopsy specimen of the distal esophagus is obtained. Which of the following microscopic changes, seen in the figure, has most likely occurred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Columnar metaplasia 

Reflux of gastric acid causes normal esophageal squamous epithelium to convert to intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells, a process called metaplasia. Goblet cells are not normally found in the esophagus and are a minor part of this change. While the lamina propria shows some inflammatory cells, it does not atrophy. The squamous epithelium remains non-dysplastic, though the metaplastic cells could progress to dysplasia if the abnormal stimuli persist. There is no significant hypertrophy in these cells.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man has had increasing abdominal size for 6 years. His liver span is 18 cm, and a CT scan shows an enlarged liver with decreased attenuation. Lab tests reveal high cholesterol and triglycerides, increased prothrombin time, and low albumin. Based on the liver's microscopic appearance, which activity likely caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Drinking beer  

Lipid vacuoles in hepatocytes indicate fatty change (steatosis), often from lipoprotein metabolism issues. Alcohol, a hepatotoxin, increases acetaldehyde, causing steatosis and hepatocyte damage, reflected by low albumin and high prothrombin time. Aspirin affects platelets, not the liver, while heroin shows few liver-specific pathologies. Exercise has little effect on liver function, and smoking primarily harms lung tissue, not the liver.

questions.text: A screening chest X-ray of a 37-year-old asymptomatic man reveals a 3-cm nodule in the right lung's middle lobe. After excision, the mass shows a sharply circumscribed area with a soft, white center. The microscopic appearance is provided, and the serum interferon gamma release assay is positive. Which pathologic process likely occurred in the nodule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Caseous necrosis  

The cheeselike appearance characterizes caseous necrosis. The figure shows amorphous pink acellular material surrounded by epithelioid macrophages, with a Langhans giant cell visible. This pattern is commonly seen in lung infections like tuberculosis and fungi. Apoptosis affects individual cells and does not result in extensive tissue necrosis.

questions.text: A 11-year-old child falls and cuts his hand. The wound becomes infected. Bacteria extend into the extracellular matrix around capillaries. In the inflammatory response to this infection, which of the following cells removes the bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Macrophage 

Macrophages, derived from circulating monocytes, are phagocytic cells that act as the body's janitorial crew. The other cells listed are not phagocytes: B cells become plasma cells that secrete antibodies, fibroblasts produce collagen for healing, and mast cells release inflammatory mediators.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman has had increasing malaise and a 10-kg weight loss over the past year, dying from massive pulmonary thromboembolism. The liver's gross appearance at autopsy is shown in the figure. Which lesions best describe her liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Metastatic adenocarcinoma  

The figure shows multiple tan metastatic lesions in the liver from adenocarcinomas, likely from the colon, pancreas, or stomach. Thromboembolism suggests a hypercoagulable state, possibly from paraneoplastic syndrome. Angiosarcomas are rare, and primary tumors typically appear as a dominant mass. Widespread nodules indicate metastases, while leukemic infiltrates do not form large masses. Resection of multiple metastases is often ineffective.
